transcripts.text: Alan now is 95 years old, great World War II hero.  And when I spoke to him, I said, come on up to the White House sometime and I'll see you.  And guess what?  He called, he said, hey, you promised and I deliver, right?  I deliver.  We don't play games.  And it's an honor to see you, Alan.  Alan is with some of his friends, Sidney Walton, World War II veteran, great gentleman, great hero.  And he's 100 years old.  And I want to be like you someday.  I want to be like all of you guys someday.  That's great.  100.  And thank you very much.  Thanks, Sidney.  That's fantastic.  Thank you.  Then Floyd Wright.  Then Floyd Wigfield.  And Paul, where's Paul?  Paul Kreiner is fantastic.  Paul is, let's see, 103.  He doesn't look a day over 90.  103.  You look fantastic.  Congratulations.  Congratulations.  War hero.  And Floyd Wakefield, who is a 101.  And you are amazing.  Look at you, huh?  Look at you.  Look at you.  I'm glad you took me up on the offer.  And surrounded by the family.  Very good genes in this family.  You live a long time, right?  You're proud of the folks?  Absolutely.  Do you have anything to say about them?  Oh, our dad's the most wonderful dad in the world.  And we're here, right?
This is our dad right here.  The most wonderful dad.  The most wonderful dad you can ever imagine.  What he's doing, Mr.  President, is incredible.
He's traveling the whole country.
All 50 governors are now meeting the President.  He's spreading the word of how few World War II veterans there are left.
Do you know how many, actually?  Do you know?  Is there a number?  It's really...
What I've been told is just a handful.
Wow.  Isn't that incredible?
He's on a year-and-a-half tour, meeting not only all the governors, but he's meeting hundreds of thousands of people along the way.

That's fantastic.  Well, congratulations on... having a great gentleman that is, you know, I'm a big believer in having good genes.  And you have the best genes you can have, right?  Thank you.  So you travel a little bit with him, do you?  Yes.  That's great.  That's fantastic.  Let me see what that says.  Sydney, 100-year-old.  No regrets.  Because he regretted not meeting a Civil War veteran when he had a chance.  And he doesn't want anyone to regret not meeting a World War II veteran.  That's really nice.  No, I don't think anybody does.  That was a great victory.  That was a great victory.  We knew how to win wars.  That was a tremendous victory.  So tell me, you talked to me the way we spoke.  We had the greatest conversation.  Tell them what we said.  Yes.  I expressed to the president at the convention last year.  He asked me to come on the stage, which was awesome.  I was afraid that the Secret Service was going to grab me when I put my arm around you.  He just wrapped his arm around me.  And I had a picture with me and asked the president if he had signed it for me.  He said he sure would.  I said to him that I was going to be 95 today, President, on April 11, and I said, Well, I'd like to bring my family to the White House and meet in the Oval Office because somebody told me that I would never get in the Oval Office.  And I really appreciate it, Mr.  President, for you allowing us to come to be with you today.  And I just wish you the best of all of your endeavors.  Thank you very much.  I've got a young man back home.  I told you not to let me speak.  That's okay.  No, he speaks well.  He speaks very well.  I've got a young man back home that comes to my church Sunday school class almost every Sunday, and your name's mentioned by him.  And I've got to get a picture to take back for him.  We'll do that.  We'll do that.  I want to ask you one other question.  Go ahead.  When you're in Pittsburgh, I'd like to be on the stage with you.  Okay.  We can do that, which will be soon.  We'll do that.  100%.  That's why he's successful, because he's very aggressive.  He's an aggressive, great guy.  Thank you very much.  I really appreciate it.  Let me have it.  Thanks, Alan.  I'm going to sign this one, right?  Yes?  I'll sign this one for you.  Okay, I'm going to sell this one.  And Paul, how about you?  Tell me.  You feeling good?  I was in a combat outfit with Ruber.  We were second longest in combat.  We had 517 days of combat.  Wow.  And I started out in Africa, Italy, France, and Germany.  I was in the Alps Mountain area when the war ended on.  Our last position was at Fusen, southern Germany, in the Elms Mountain area.  We were pulled out and went into Schongau, a German army camp, where they trained air prayers identification people.  And we processed 14,000 prisoners there in two weeks.  It would be amazing, right?  So do you remember those days perfectly?  Yes, sir.  That's really something.  I was also in the Korean War, too.  You're a warrior, isn't he?  Twenty-six months in there.  One hundred and three.  Boy, you're going to be around a long time.  You look fantastic.  You look fantastic, and I really appreciate you being in the White House and the Oval Office.  Tell us something about the man.  Or his.  Tell us, go ahead.  He's not shy, you know.  No, he's not shy.  He's not shy at all.  I'm just like him.  This is my brother.  Congratulations.

We're very proud of Dad.  Dad was one of five brothers that went off to World War II.  And his mom was a Gold Star mother.  One of them then returned.  Oh, wow.  So Dad is very proud to be a World War II veteran with his family and God.  We're proud of him.

Proud of all of you.  Floyd, how about yourself?  I'm with the force of aging.  We went in on Utah Beach.  June of 20... June of 44.  We made the... I wish I had that.  We made a third, he was on the third wave.  And it was pretty brutal.  It was a pretty brutal area at the time, wasn't it?  Yeah.
I was there about a half a month before I got wounded.
Night and day on the battlefield.  How badly wounded?  Were you badly wounded?

Yeah, well I was all summer there getting me, getting me back out of the hospital.  They sent me back up, went back up into Germany somewhere and sent another shell back in, back in France, back in England again and that time they sent me home.
Yes.  Fantastic job.  You together?

Paul and Floyd work with the Greatest Generations Foundation.  As you know, we return combat veterans back to where they fought and served.  And we look forward to hosting you in Normandy This coming June for the 75th.
I'll be there.
Probably a good opportunity.  This gentleman wants to fly back with you on Air Force One.
Where are you flying back to?  Are you flying back to Washington?
Once we're done in Europe.

We'll do that.  We'll work that out.  Is that okay?  We'll work that out.  You'll like Air Force One.  Well, I want to thank all of you.  Great heroes.  Great warriors.  Highly respected.  And you folks do a fantastic job.  Thank you.  I want to thank you.  Congratulations to everybody.  Yes, please.
President Trump, my father just wanted to say a couple of things.
Yes, please.
Dad, please tell the president the reason why you joined the Army.
I joined the Army to fight Hitler.
That's the reason he joined.
That was a good reason.
And it's called now the No Regrets Tour.  You regret not meeting the Civil War veterans.
Yes, I regret not meeting them.
And he's serving war veterans.  And that's why he's allowing people that want to meet a World War II veteran before it's too late to meet him.
That's great.
And he brought a gift for you.
Good.
And we have the gift back there.  I think you'll love it.  It's a very special gift that my dad's carrying.

You want to bring it up?  San Diego.  From San Diego, just for you.  Great.  Well we just built a wall.  And they were very happy that I built it.  Oh, that's beautiful.  That's beautiful.  That's fantastic.  Thank you very much.  And all my dad asks is if you happen to know how to tweet, if you want to tweet that out.  I don't tweet too much.  I'll do something.  We'll have a little fun.  Yes?  Yes?
Is this one of the best days of your life?

Yes, that's great.  You have a great family.  Well, I want to thank everybody.  These are just terrific people.  We weren't going to do this with the media, but frankly, when I saw you, I said, we have to.  And thank you.  Great job.  Go ahead, please.  Mr.  President, I want you to meet my wife.  We've been married 69 years.  Whoa.  She probably can tell you more about me than I can tell myself.  Give us just the good stuff, not the bad stuff.  Well, is there much to say then?  It's all been good.  That's great.  Couldn't be any better.  That's really nice.  I can see that on your face.  I can see that.  Thank you.  Thank you all very much.  It's a great honor.  Thank you.  Thank you all very much.
